Literature Review: The advent of single-molecule imaging techniques has revolutionized our understanding of mRNA dynamics within individual cells, providing unprecedented insights into the complex life cycle of these crucial molecules. This literature review aims to explore the recent advances in studying mRNA birth, life, and death at the single-cell level, focusing on the interconnected processes of transcription, splicing, localization, translation, and decay.Transcription, the birth of mRNA, has been a subject of intense study using single-molecule approaches. Larson et al. (2011) pioneered the use of MS2-GFP labeling to visualize nascent transcripts in living cells, revealing the kinetics of RNA polymerase II elongation and promoter-proximal pausing. Building on this work, Cho et al. (2016) developed a multi-color imaging system to simultaneously track multiple genes, uncovering the dynamics of transcriptional bursting and its regulation by enhancers.The coupling of transcription and splicing has been a topic of particular interest in recent years. Martin et al. (2013) used live-cell imaging to demonstrate that splicing can occur co-transcriptionally, with introns being removed mere seconds after their synthesis. This finding was further supported by Coulon et al. (2014), who employed a combination of MS2 and PP7 labeling to show that splicing efficiency is influenced by transcription elongation rates.Following transcription and splicing, mRNA localization plays a crucial role in determining protein distribution and cellular function. Buxbaum et al. (2015) developed the FISH-quant method to quantify mRNA localization patterns in fixed cells with high precision. This technique was later adapted for live-cell imaging by Tutucci et al. (2018), who used it to track the movement of individual mRNAs in real-time, revealing the dynamic nature of RNA localization and its dependence on cytoskeletal elements.Translation, the process by which mRNAs are decoded into proteins, has also benefited from single-molecule imaging approaches. Wu et al. (2016) developed a method to visualize single translation events in living cells, providing direct evidence for the existence of polysomes and revealing the kinetics of ribosome initiation and elongation. Morisaki et al. (2016) further expanded on this work by simultaneously imaging nascent proteins and their cognate mRNAs, demonstrating the spatial coupling of translation to specific subcellular locations.The final stage in the mRNA life cycle, decay, has been challenging to study at the single-molecule level due to the rapid nature of the process. However, Trcek et al. (2012) developed a method to visualize mRNA decay in real-time using a combination of MS2 labeling and a fluorescence-based timer. This approach revealed that mRNA decay is often initiated at specific cellular locations and can be influenced by the translation status of the transcript.Recent studies have begun to integrate these various aspects of mRNA metabolism to provide a more holistic view of gene expression regulation. For example, Garcia et al. (2013) used a combination of single-molecule imaging techniques to simultaneously track transcription, nuclear export, and cytoplasmic degradation of individual mRNAs. This work revealed that these processes are tightly coupled and that perturbations in one step can have far-reaching consequences on overall gene expression.The application of single-molecule imaging techniques to multicellular systems and whole organisms represents an exciting frontier in the field. Chen et al. (2019) adapted single-molecule FISH techniques for use in Drosophila embryos, providing insights into the spatial regulation of gene expression during development. Similarly, Lionnet et al. (2011) developed methods for imaging single mRNAs in living mice, opening up new possibilities for studying RNA metabolism in the context of complex tissues and organs.As the field continues to advance, new challenges and opportunities are emerging. The development of more sensitive and specific labeling techniques, such as those based on CRISPR-Cas9 (Nelles et al., 2016), promises to expand the repertoire of RNAs that can be studied at the single-molecule level. Additionally, the integration of single-molecule imaging with other high-throughput techniques, such as single-cell RNA sequencing, has the potential to provide a more comprehensive understanding of gene expression heterogeneity within cell populations.In conclusion, single-molecule imaging techniques have transformed our understanding of mRNA dynamics, providing unprecedented insights into the birth, life, and death of these crucial molecules. As these methods continue to evolve and are applied to more complex biological systems, they promise to reveal new layers of regulation in gene expression and cellular function.
